He had noticed, however, that the prisoner on the other side had ceased to labor; no matter, this was a greater reason for proceeding—if his neighbor would not come to him, he would go to his neighbor. All day he toiled on untiringly, and by the evening he had succeeded in extracting ten handfuls of plaster and fragments of stone. When the hour for his jailer’s visit arrived, Dantès straightened the handle of the saucepan as well as he could, and placed it in its accustomed place. The turnkey poured his ration of soup into it, together with the fish—for thrice a week the prisoners were deprived of meat. This would have been a method of reckoning time, had not Dantès long ceased to do so. Having poured out the soup, the turnkey retired.
Dantès wished to ascertain whether his neighbor had really ceased to work. He listened—all was silent, as it had been for the last three days. Dantès sighed; it was evident that his neighbor distrusted him. However, he toiled on all the night without being discouraged; but after two or three hours he encountered an obstacle. The iron made no impression, but met with a smooth surface; Dantès touched it, and found that it was a beam. This beam crossed, or rather blocked up, the hole Dantès had made; it was necessary, therefore, to dig above or under it. The unhappy young man had not thought of this.
“Oh, my God, my God!” murmured he, “I have so earnestly prayed to you, that I hoped my prayers had been heard. After having deprived me of my liberty, after having deprived me of death, after having recalled me to existence, my God, have pity on me, and do not let me die in despair!”
“Who talks of God and despair at the same time?” said a voice that seemed to come from beneath the earth, and, deadened by the distance, sounded hollow and sepulchral in the young man’s ears. Edmond’s hair stood on end, and he rose to his knees.

At the first blow the sound ceased, as if by magic. Edmond paused, his heart pounding in his chest. The silence that followed was more unnerving than the noise itself. He strained his ears, listening for any sign of movement, any whisper of life beyond the thick stone walls of the Château d'If. But there was nothing—only the distant echo of the sea and the faint rustle of his own breath.

For a moment, doubt crept into his mind. Had he imagined the sound? Had his years of solitude finally driven him to madness? But no—he had heard it, clear as day. A rhythmic tapping, like a prisoner signaling for help. And now, as suddenly as it had begun, it had stopped.

Edmond raised his pickaxe again, hesitating. If he struck the wall once more, would the sound return? Or would he only confirm his own isolation? He clenched his jaw, determination hardening his resolve. He had spent years in this cell, plotting his revenge, honing his mind and body for the day he would escape. If there was even the slightest chance that another soul was trapped nearby, he could not ignore it.

With a swift, powerful motion, he brought the pickaxe down against the wall. The impact sent a sharp jolt through his arms, but this time, there was no answering sound. Only the dull thud of metal against stone. Edmond’s shoulders slumped. Perhaps he had been mistaken after all.

Then—just as he was about to turn away—a faint, hesitant tap echoed through the wall. It was softer than before, as though the source of the sound had grown weaker. Edmond’s breath caught in his throat. He was not alone.

He struck the wall again, this time with more force. The response came quicker now, a series of rapid taps that seemed to grow in confidence. Edmond’s pulse quickened. It was a code—a prisoner’s language, one he had heard rumors of but never thought to use himself. He tapped back, mimicking the pattern. The response was immediate, a flurry of sound that conveyed both relief and urgency.

For hours, the two prisoners communicated through the wall, their taps forming a crude but effective dialogue. Edmond learned that his neighbor was an old man, a fellow victim of injustice who had been imprisoned even longer than he had. The man’s name was Abbé Faria, and he claimed to possess knowledge that could change Edmond’s life forever.

As the days passed, their secret exchanges became the highlight of Edmond’s existence. The Abbé spoke of hidden treasure, of vengeance, of a world beyond the Château d’If where justice could be served. With each conversation, Edmond’s hope grew stronger. No longer was he merely a prisoner—he was a man with a purpose, a destiny.

One night, after months of careful planning, Edmond and the Abbé finally broke through the wall separating their cells. The moment their hands clasped in the dim light of the dungeon, Edmond knew his life would never be the same. The Abbé’s eyes gleamed with intelligence and cunning, and his words carried the weight of truth.

“Together,” the old man whispered, “we will escape this place. And then, Edmond Dantès, you will become the Count of Monte Cristo.”

From that moment on, Edmond’s path was clear. The sound that had ceased at the first blow had been the beginning of his transformation. The silence had been a test—one he had passed. And now, with the Abbé’s guidance, he would rise from the depths of the Château d’If to claim his revenge.

The Count of Monte Cristo was born in that darkness, forged by suffering and hardened by resolve. And the world would soon learn the price of betrayal.

events.title: Revelation and a Shared Future: The Neighbor Emerges
detailed_summary: Dantès, astonished and terrified, acknowledged the human voice—the first he'd heard besides his jailer's in years.

He and the voice exchanged information: they were both unhappy prisoners; Dantès was a French sailor named Edmond Dantès, imprisoned since February 1815 for allegedly conspiring for Napoleon's return.
The voice revealed he had been imprisoned since 1811, shocking Dantès with the length of his captivity, and was unaware of Napoleon's abdication.
The other prisoner, identifying himself only as No. 27, explained that a miscalculation in his escape plans led him to Dantès' cell instead of the outer fortress wall and proximity to the sea.
No. 27 advised Dantès to seal his excavation and wait. Sensing mistrust and fearing abandonment, Dantès passionately swore his loyalty, threatening self-destruction if left alone.
Reassured by Dantès' youth (not yet twenty-six) and fervent pleas, No. 27 promised not to forsake him and to provide a signal after calculating their chances.
Dantès, overjoyed at the prospect of companionship and potential liberty, expressed his deep loneliness and offered his unwavering affection and loyalty, whether as a comrade or a son.
No. 27 confirmed, "tomorrow," leaving Dantès ecstatic. He spent the day in anticipation, resolving to kill the jailer if any attempt was made to separate him from his new acquaintance.
The next morning, after the jailer's departure and an exchange of knocks, No. 27 resumed work. Suddenly, the floor in Dantès' cell gave way, and from the resulting hole, a man emerged into his cell.

“Ah,” said he, “I hear a human voice.” Edmond had not heard anyone speak save his jailer for four or five years; and a jailer is no man to a prisoner—he is a living door, a barrier of flesh and blood adding strength to restraints of oak and iron.
“In the name of Heaven,” cried Dantès, “speak again, though the sound of your voice terrifies me. Who are you?”
“Who are you?” said the voice.
“An unhappy prisoner,” replied Dantès, who made no hesitation in answering.
“Of what country?”
“A Frenchman.”
“Your name?”
“Edmond Dantès.”
“Your profession?”
“A sailor.”
“How long have you been here?”
“Since the 28th of February, 1815.”
“Your crime?”
“I am innocent.”
“But of what are you accused?”
“Of having conspired to aid the emperor’s return.”
“What! For the emperor’s return?—the emperor is no longer on the throne, then?”
“He abdicated at Fontainebleau in 1814, and was sent to the Island of Elba. But how long have you been here that you are ignorant of all this?”
“Since 1811.”
Dantès shuddered; this man had been four years longer than himself in prison.
“Do not dig any more,” said the voice; “only tell me how high up is your excavation?”
“On a level with the floor.”
“How is it concealed?”
“Behind my bed.”
“Has your bed been moved since you have been a prisoner?”
“No.”
“What does your chamber open on?”
“A corridor.”
“And the corridor?”
“On a court.”
“Alas!” murmured the voice.
“Oh, what is the matter?” cried Dantès.
“I have made a mistake owing to an error in my plans. I took the wrong angle, and have come out fifteen feet from where I intended. I took the wall you are mining for the outer wall of the fortress.”
“But then you would be close to the sea?”
“That is what I hoped.”
“And supposing you had succeeded?”
“I should have thrown myself into the sea, gained one of the islands near here—the Isle de Daume or the Isle de Tiboulen—and then I should have been safe.”
“Could you have swum so far?”
“Heaven would have given me strength; but now all is lost.”
“All?”
“Yes; stop up your excavation carefully, do not work any more, and wait until you hear from me.”
“Tell me, at least, who you are?”
“I am—I am No. 27.”
“You mistrust me, then,” said Dantès. Edmond fancied he heard a bitter laugh resounding from the depths.
“Oh, I am a Christian,” cried Dantès, guessing instinctively that this man meant to abandon him. “I swear to you by him who died for us that naught shall induce me to breathe one syllable to my jailers; but I conjure you do not abandon me. If you do, I swear to you, for I have got to the end of my strength, that I will dash my brains out against the wall, and you will have my death to reproach yourself with.”
“How old are you? Your voice is that of a young man.”
“I do not know my age, for I have not counted the years I have been here. All I do know is, that I was just nineteen when I was arrested, the 28th of February, 1815.”
“Not quite twenty-six!” murmured the voice; “at that age he cannot be a traitor.”
“Oh, no, no,” cried Dantès. “I swear to you again, rather than betray you, I would allow myself to be hacked in pieces!”
“You have done well to speak to me, and ask for my assistance, for I was about to form another plan, and leave you; but your age reassures me. I will not forget you. Wait.”
“How long?”
“I must calculate our chances; I will give you the signal.”
“But you will not leave me; you will come to me, or you will let me come to you. We will escape, and if we cannot escape we will talk; you of those whom you love, and I of those whom I love. You must love somebody?”
“No, I am alone in the world.”
“Then you will love me. If you are young, I will be your comrade; if you are old, I will be your son. I have a father who is seventy if he yet lives; I only love him and a young girl called Mercédès. My father has not yet forgotten me, I am sure, but God alone knows if she loves me still; I shall love you as I loved my father.”
“It is well,” returned the voice; “tomorrow.”
These few words were uttered with an accent that left no doubt of his sincerity; Dantès rose, dispersed the fragments with the same precaution as before, and pushed his bed back against the wall. He then gave himself up to his happiness. He would no longer be alone. He was, perhaps, about to regain his liberty; at the worst, he would have a companion, and captivity that is shared is but half captivity. Plaints made in common are almost prayers, and prayers where two or three are gathered together invoke the mercy of heaven.
All day Dantès walked up and down his cell. He sat down occasionally on his bed, pressing his hand on his heart. At the slightest noise he bounded towards the door. Once or twice the thought crossed his mind that he might be separated from this unknown, whom he loved already; and then his mind was made up—when the jailer moved his bed and stooped to examine the opening, he would kill him with his water jug. He would be condemned to die, but he was about to die of grief and despair when this miraculous noise recalled him to life.
The jailer came in the evening. Dantès was on his bed. It seemed to him that thus he better guarded the unfinished opening. Doubtless there was a strange expression in his eyes, for the jailer said, “Come, are you going mad again?”
Dantès did not answer; he feared that the emotion of his voice would betray him. The jailer went away shaking his head. Night came; Dantès hoped that his neighbor would profit by the silence to address him, but he was mistaken. The next morning, however, just as he removed his bed from the wall, he heard three knocks; he threw himself on his knees.
“Is it you?” said he; “I am here.”
“Is your jailer gone?”
“Yes,” said Dantès; “he will not return until the evening; so that we have twelve hours before us.”
“I can work, then?” said the voice.
“Oh, yes, yes; this instant, I entreat you.”
In a moment that part of the floor on which Dantès was resting his two hands, as he knelt with his head in the opening, suddenly gave way; he drew back smartly, while a mass of stones and earth disappeared in a hole that opened beneath the aperture he himself had formed. Then from the bottom of this passage, the depth of which it was impossible to measure, he saw appear, first the head, then the shoulders, and lastly the body of a man, who sprang lightly into his cell.

He turned towards the direction whence the sound came, and said, “In the name of Heaven, speak again, though the sound of your voice terrifies me.”  

“Who are you?” said the voice.  

“An unhappy prisoner,” replied Dantès, without hesitation.  

“Of what country?”  

“A Frenchman.”  

“Your name?”  

“Edmond Dantès.”  

“Your profession?”  

“A sailor.”  

“How long have you been here?”  

“Since the 28th of February, 1815.”  

“Your crime?”  

“I am innocent.”  

“But of what are you accused?”  

“Of having conspired for the return of Napoleon.”  

“What! For the return of Napoleon! Has he then abdicated?”  

“He abdicated at Fontainebleau in 1814, and was sent to the Island of Elba. But how long have you been here that you are ignorant of all this?”  

“Since 1811.”  

Dantès shuddered; this man had been four years longer than himself in prison.  

“Do not dig any more,” said the voice; “only tell me how high up is your excavation?”  

“On a level with the floor.”  

“How is it concealed?”  

“Behind my bed.”  

“Has your bed been moved since you have been a prisoner?”  

“No.”  

“What does your chamber open on?”  

“A corridor.”  

“And the corridor?”  

“On a court.”  

“Alas!” murmured the voice.  

“Oh, what is the matter?” cried Dantès.  

“I am deceived, and the imperfection of my plans has ruined all. An error of a line in the plan has been equivalent to fifteen feet in reality, and I took the wall you are mining for the outer wall of the fortress.”  

“But then you would have reached the sea?”  

“That was what I hoped.”  

“And supposing you had succeeded?”  

“I should have thrown myself into the sea, gained one of the islands near here—the Isle de Daume or the Isle de Tiboulen—and then I was safe.”  

“Could you have swum so far?”  

“Heaven would have given me strength; but now all is lost.”  

“All?”  

“Yes; stop up your excavation carefully, do not work any more, and wait until you hear from me.”  

“Tell me, at least, who you are?”  

“I am—I am No. 27.”  

“You mistrust me, then?” said Dantès.  

The voice hesitated.  

“Oh, I swear to you,” cried Dantès, “by the name of Jesus Christ, that I would rather let myself be killed than betray you or your companions. If you abandon me, I swear to you that I will dash my brains out against the wall, and you will have my death to reproach yourself with.”  

“How old are you? Your voice is that of a young man.”  

“I do not know my age, for I have not counted the years I have been here. All I know is, that I was just nineteen when I was arrested, the 28th of February, 1815.”  

“Not quite twenty-six!” murmured the voice; “at that age he cannot be a traitor.”  

“Oh, no, no!” cried Dantès. “I swear to you again, rather than betray you, I would suffer myself to be hacked in pieces!”  

“You have done well to speak to me, and ask for my assistance, for I was about to form another plan, and leave you; but your age reassures me. I will not forget you. Expect me.”  

“When?”  

“I must calculate our chances; I will give you the signal.”  

“But you will not abandon me; you will come to me, or you will let me come to you. We will escape, and if we cannot escape, we will talk; you of those whom you love, and I of those whom I love. You must love some one?”  

“No, I am alone in the world.”  

“Then you will love me. If you are young, I will be your comrade; if you are old, I will be your son. I have a father who is seventy if he yet lives; I only love him and a young girl called Mercédès. My father has not forgotten me, I am sure; but God alone knows if she loves me still. I shall love you as I loved my father.”  

“It is well,” returned the voice; “to-morrow.”

He was, perhaps, about to regain his liberty; at the worst, he would have a companion, and captivity shared with another was but half captivity.  

Pleasures, like pains, are rendered greater by sharing.  

The next morning, just as the jailer withdrew from his visit, Dantès heard the three knocks at intervals; he threw himself on his knees.  

“Is it you?” said he; “I am here.”  

“Has your jailer gone?”  

“Yes,” said Dantès; “he will not return until the evening; we have twelve hours before us.”  

“I can work, then,” said the voice.  

“Oh, yes, yes; this instant, I entreat you.”  

In a moment that part of the floor on which Dantès was resting his two hands, as he knelt with his head in the opening, suddenly yielded; he drew back smartly, while a mass of stones and earth disappeared in a hole that opened beneath the aperture he himself had formed. Then from the bottom of this passage, the depth of which it was impossible to measure, he saw appear, first the head, then the shoulders, and lastly the body of a man, who sprang lightly into his cell.  

---

"Ah," said he, "I hear a human voice."  

The words echoed faintly through the damp, oppressive darkness of the Château d'If. Edmond Dantès, imprisoned for fourteen long years in that accursed fortress, had grown accustomed to the silence of his cell—broken only by the occasional clank of chains or the distant murmur of the sea. But this sound was different. It was the voice of another man, weak yet unmistakably human.  

For years, Dantès had believed himself utterly alone, abandoned by the world. The injustice of his imprisonment had gnawed at his soul, transforming him from an innocent young sailor into a man consumed by thoughts of vengeance. Yet now, this voice—frail, trembling—pierced through his despair like a sliver of light in the abyss.  

He pressed his ear against the cold stone wall, straining to hear more. The voice came again, muffled but distinct.  

"Who is there?" Dantès called out, his own voice hoarse from disuse.  

A pause. Then, the reply: "A fellow prisoner, if you can believe it. I had begun to think myself the only living soul in this tomb."  

Dantès’ heart quickened. "How long have you been here?"  

"Years," came the answer. "Though time loses all meaning in this place. I am Abbé Faria."  

The name meant nothing to Dantès, yet the mere fact of another’s presence filled him with a strange exhilaration. Here, at last, was someone to speak to, someone who might understand his suffering.  

"I am Edmond Dantès," he replied. "A sailor, wrongly accused."  

"A common fate in these walls," Faria said with a dry chuckle. "But tell me, what was your crime?"  

"Treason, they said. Though I swear before God, I am innocent."  

The abbé sighed. "Innocence is no shield against the malice of men. But come, let us not dwell on our misfortunes. If we are to be neighbors, we may as well make the best of it."  

And so began an unlikely friendship, forged through the walls of their adjoining cells. At first, their conversations were brief, cautious. But as days turned into weeks, they spoke for hours—of their pasts, their hopes, their dreams. Faria, a learned man, shared his vast knowledge with Dantès, teaching him history, philosophy, languages, and the sciences. In turn, Dantès spoke of the sea, of his love for Mercédès, and of the betrayal that had condemned him to this living death.  

One evening, as the flickering light of Dantès’ lamp cast long shadows across the stone, Faria’s voice took on a new intensity.  

"Edmond," he said, "I have something to tell you. A secret I have kept for many years."  

Dantès leaned closer. "What is it?"  

"I know of a vast treasure," Faria whispered. "Hidden on the island of Monte Cristo. It was left there by the Spada family, and its value is beyond imagining."  

Dantès frowned. "A treasure? How do you know of this?"  

Faria explained how, as a former advisor to Italian nobility, he had uncovered the secret through ancient documents. He had intended to retrieve it himself, but his arrest had dashed those hopes. Now, he saw in Dantès the means to fulfill his own thwarted destiny.  

"If you ever escape this place," Faria said, "the treasure is yours. But you must swear to use it wisely."  

Dantès hesitated. The idea seemed fantastical, yet Faria’s earnestness was undeniable. "I swear it," he said at last.  

Weeks passed, and their plans grew more elaborate. Faria, ever the scholar, devised a scheme for their escape—a tunnel through the stone, painstakingly dug with makeshift tools. But fate, it seemed, had other designs. One night, Faria fell gravely ill, his body wracked by seizures.  

Dantès, helpless, could only listen as his friend’s breathing grew labored. "Do not leave me," he pleaded.  

Faria’s voice was barely a whisper. "The treasure… remember… Monte Cristo…"  

And then, silence.  

Dantès wept for the first time in years. Faria had been more than a friend—he had been a father, a teacher, a beacon of hope. Now, he was gone.  

But even in death, Faria offered one final gift. When the guards came to remove his body, Dantès concealed himself in the abbé’s burial sack, allowing himself to be carried out of the cell. As he was thrown into the sea, he cut his way free, gasping as the cold water embraced him.  

He swam with desperate strength, the waves crashing around him, until at last, he reached the shore. Free.  

Standing on the beach, dripping and exhausted, Dantès looked back at the dark silhouette of the Château d’If. The past was dead. The future awaited.  

And in his heart, a single thought burned like a brand: *Vengeance.*  

For he was no longer Edmond Dantès, the innocent sailor. He was the Count of Monte Cristo, and the world would soon know his wrath.

events.text_segment:
Seizing in his arms the friend so long and ardently desired, Dantès almost carried him towards the window, in order to obtain a better view of his features by the aid of the imperfect light that struggled through the grating.
He was a man of small stature, with hair blanched rather by suffering and sorrow than by age. He had a deep-set, penetrating eye, almost buried beneath the thick gray eyebrow, and a long (and still black) beard reaching down to his breast. His thin face, deeply furrowed by care, and the bold outline of his strongly marked features, betokened a man more accustomed to exercise his mental faculties than his physical strength. Large drops of perspiration were now standing on his brow, while the garments that hung about him were so ragged that one could only guess at the pattern upon which they had originally been fashioned.
The stranger might have numbered sixty or sixty-five years; but a certain briskness and appearance of vigor in his movements made it probable that he was aged more from captivity than the course of time. He received the enthusiastic greeting of his young acquaintance with evident pleasure, as though his chilled affections were rekindled and invigorated by his contact with one so warm and ardent. He thanked him with grateful cordiality for his kindly welcome, although he must at that moment have been suffering bitterly to find another dungeon where he had fondly reckoned on discovering a means of regaining his liberty.
“Let us first see,” said he, “whether it is possible to remove the traces of my entrance here—our future tranquillity depends upon our jailers being entirely ignorant of it.”
Advancing to the opening, he stooped and raised the stone easily in spite of its weight; then, fitting it into its place, he said:
“You removed this stone very carelessly; but I suppose you had no tools to aid you.”
“Why,” exclaimed Dantès, with astonishment, “do you possess any?”
“I made myself some; and with the exception of a file, I have all that are necessary,—a chisel, pincers, and lever.”
“Oh, how I should like to see these products of your industry and patience.”
“Well, in the first place, here is my chisel.”
So saying, he displayed a sharp strong blade, with a handle made of beechwood.
“And with what did you contrive to make that?” inquired Dantès.
“With one of the clamps of my bedstead; and this very tool has sufficed me to hollow out the road by which I came hither, a distance of about fifty feet.”
“Fifty feet!” responded Dantès, almost terrified.

“Do not speak so loud, young man—don’t speak so loud. It frequently occurs in a state prison like this, that persons are stationed outside the doors of the cells purposely to overhear the conversation of the prisoners.”
“But they believe I am shut up alone here.”
“That makes no difference.”
“And you say that you dug your way a distance of fifty feet to get here?”
“I do; that is about the distance that separates your chamber from mine; only, unfortunately, I did not curve aright; for want of the necessary geometrical instruments to calculate my scale of proportion, instead of taking an ellipsis of forty feet, I made it fifty. I expected, as I told you, to reach the outer wall, pierce through it, and throw myself into the sea; I have, however, kept along the corridor on which your chamber opens, instead of going beneath it. My labor is all in vain, for I find that the corridor looks into a courtyard filled with soldiers.”
“That’s true,” said Dantès; “but the corridor you speak of only bounds one side of my cell; there are three others—do you know anything of their situation?”
“This one is built against the solid rock, and it would take ten experienced miners, duly furnished with the requisite tools, as many years to perforate it. This adjoins the lower part of the governor’s apartments, and were we to work our way through, we should only get into some lock-up cellars, where we must necessarily be recaptured. The fourth and last side of your cell faces on—faces on—stop a minute, now where does it face?”
The wall of which he spoke was the one in which was fixed the loophole by which light was admitted to the chamber. This loophole, which gradually diminished in size as it approached the outside, to an opening through which a child could not have passed, was, for better security, furnished with three iron bars, so as to quiet all apprehensions even in the mind of the most suspicious jailer as to the possibility of a prisoner’s escape. As the stranger asked the question, he dragged the table beneath the window.
“Climb up,” said he to Dantès.
The young man obeyed, mounted on the table, and, divining the wishes of his companion, placed his back securely against the wall and held out both hands. The stranger, whom as yet Dantès knew only by the number of his cell, sprang up with an agility by no means to be expected in a person of his years, and, light and steady on his feet as a cat or a lizard, climbed from the table to the outstretched hands of Dantès, and from them to his shoulders; then, bending double, for the ceiling of the dungeon prevented him from holding himself erect, he managed to slip his head between the upper bars of the window, so as to be able to command a perfect view from top to bottom.
An instant afterwards he hastily drew back his head, saying, “I thought so!” and sliding from the shoulders of Dantès as dextrously as he had ascended, he nimbly leaped from the table to the ground.

detailed_summary: Dantès anxiously asks what the stranger discovered after quickly withdrawing from the window.
The stranger confirms his suspicion: that side of the cell overlooks an open gallery continuously patrolled by sentries, day and night, explaining he saw a soldier's outline and musket.
He concludes that escape through Dantès' dungeon is completely impossible.
Upon this realization, the older prisoner expresses profound resignation, uttering that God's will be done, an attitude that fills Dantès with astonished admiration.
Deeply impressed, Dantès implores the man to reveal his identity, stating he has never met anyone so remarkable.
The stranger, with a sad smile, agrees to share his story, introducing himself as the Abbé Faria.
Faria recounts that he has been imprisoned in the Château d’If since 1811, following a three-year confinement in the fortress of Fenestrelle.

He mentions learning of Napoleon's son, the King of Rome, around the time of his transfer in 1811, and expresses surprise at the news of Napoleon's overthrow four years later, inquiring about the current ruler of France.
When Dantès informs him Louis XVIII is king, Faria reflects on the inscrutable ways of Providence, marveling at how Heaven humbles the exalted and elevates the humbled.
Dantès is entirely captivated by Faria, who can contemplate the destinies of nations while forgetting his own dire situation.

“What was it that you thought?” asked the young man anxiously, in his turn descending from the table.
The elder prisoner pondered the matter. “Yes,” said he at length, “it is so. This side of your chamber looks out upon a kind of open gallery, where patrols are continually passing, and sentries keep watch day and night.”
“Are you quite sure of that?”
“Certain. I saw the soldier’s shape and the top of his musket; that made me draw in my head so quickly, for I was fearful he might also see me.”
“Well?” inquired Dantès.
“You perceive then the utter impossibility of escaping through your dungeon?”
“Then——” pursued the young man eagerly.
“Then,” answered the elder prisoner, “the will of God be done!” And as the old man slowly pronounced those words, an air of profound resignation spread itself over his careworn countenance. Dantès gazed on the man who could thus philosophically resign hopes so long and ardently nourished with an astonishment mingled with admiration.
“Tell me, I entreat of you, who and what you are?” said he at length. “Never have I met with so remarkable a person as yourself.”
“Willingly,” answered the stranger; “if, indeed, you feel any curiosity respecting one, now, alas, powerless to aid you in any way.”
“Say not so; you can console and support me by the strength of your own powerful mind. Pray let me know who you really are?”
The stranger smiled a melancholy smile. “Then listen,” said he. “I am the Abbé Faria, and have been imprisoned as you know in this Château d’If since the year 1811; previously to which I had been confined for three years in the fortress of Fenestrelle. In the year 1811 I was transferred to Piedmont in France. It was at this period I learned that the destiny which seemed subservient to every wish formed by Napoleon, had bestowed on him a son, named king of Rome even in his cradle. I was very far then from expecting the change you have just informed me of; namely, that four years afterwards, this colossus of power would be overthrown. Then who reigns in France at this moment—Napoleon II.?”
“No, Louis XVIII.”
“The brother of Louis XVI.! How inscrutable are the ways of Providence—for what great and mysterious purpose has it pleased Heaven to abase the man once so elevated, and raise up him who was so abased?”
Dantès’ whole attention was riveted on a man who could thus forget his own misfortunes while occupying himself with the destinies of others.

events.title: Faria's Political Ideals and Inquiry about Reputed Madness

Faria concedes their captive state but admits there are moments his mind transcends the prison walls, making him feel free.

He laments that Italy seems fated to misfortune, referencing failed attempts by Alexander VI and Clement VII, and Napoleon's incomplete work, then bows his head in sorrow.
Dantès finds it difficult to comprehend risking one's life for such abstract political goals, his understanding limited to Napoleon and not historical figures like Clement VII or Alexander VI.
Dantès then cautiously asks if Faria is the priest widely believed to be 'ill' or, as Faria interjects, 'mad'.
Faria, with a bitter smile, acknowledges that he is indeed the 'poor mad prisoner' of Château d’If, whose supposed insanity has been a source of amusement for visitors for years.

“Yes, yes,” continued he, “’Twill be the same as it was in England. After Charles I., Cromwell; after Cromwell, Charles II., and then James II., and then some son-in-law or relation, some Prince of Orange, a stadtholder who becomes a king. Then new concessions to the people, then a constitution, then liberty. Ah, my friend!” said the abbé, turning towards Dantès, and surveying him with the kindling gaze of a prophet, “you are young, you will see all this come to pass.”
“Probably, if ever I get out of prison!”
“True,” replied Faria, “we are prisoners; but I forget this sometimes, and there are even moments when my mental vision transports me beyond these walls, and I fancy myself at liberty.”
“But wherefore are you here?”
“Because in 1807 I dreamed of the very plan Napoleon tried to realize in 1811; because, like Machiavelli, I desired to alter the political face of Italy, and instead of allowing it to be split up into a quantity of petty principalities, each held by some weak or tyrannical ruler, I sought to form one large, compact, and powerful empire; and, lastly, because I fancied I had found my Cæsar Borgia in a crowned simpleton, who feigned to enter into my views only to betray me. It was the plan of Alexander VI. and Clement VII., but it will never succeed now, for they attempted it fruitlessly, and Napoleon was unable to complete his work. Italy seems fated to misfortune.” And the old man bowed his head.
Dantès could not understand a man risking his life for such matters. Napoleon certainly he knew something of, inasmuch as he had seen and spoken with him; but of Clement VII. and Alexander VI. he knew nothing.
“Are you not,” he asked, “the priest who here in the Château d’If is generally thought to be—ill?”
“Mad, you mean, don’t you?”
“I did not like to say so,” answered Dantès, smiling.
“Well, then,” resumed Faria with a bitter smile, “let me answer your question in full, by acknowledging that I am the poor mad prisoner of the Château d’If, for many years permitted to amuse the different visitors with what is said to be my insanity; and, in all probability, I should be promoted to the honor of making sport for the children, if such innocent beings could be found in an abode devoted like this to suffering and despair.”

events.title: Faria's Despair and Dantès' Spark of Hope
detailed_summary: After a moment of silent contemplation, Dantès asks Faria if he has completely given up hope of escaping.
Faria responds that he perceives its utter impossibility and now considers it irreverent to attempt what the Almighty evidently does not approve.
Dantès tries to encourage him, suggesting that success should not be expected on the first attempt and questioning why Faria doesn't try a different direction.
Faria explains the immense personal cost of his frustrated effort, detailing the four years spent making tools and two years of arduous digging through rock-hard earth.
He describes the titanic labor of moving huge stones and the difficulty of concealing the excavated debris, which he managed by filling a hollow staircase, now completely choked.

Faria emphasizes that he had meticulously conserved his strength for this single, ultimately dashed, endeavor, and now, with his hopes crushed, nothing will induce him to renew attempts that seem contrary to divine will.
Dantès lowers his head, concealing his elation at having a companion, a feeling that surpasses his sympathy for the abbé's failed escape.
The narrative notes that the idea of escape had never occurred to Dantès before, given the seemingly insurmountable obstacles involved in such an undertaking.
However, witnessing Faria's desperate courage and near success, despite his age and physical weakness, instills new courage and ideas in Dantès.

He reasons that if an older, weaker man could accomplish so much, failing only due to a calculation error, then he, younger and stronger, could surely succeed. Faria's perseverance in creating tools and attempting the escape inspires Dantès to believe it possible for himself.

Dantès contrasts Faria's three years of labor at fifty with his own youth, willing to sacrifice six years, and Faria's scholarly background with his own skills as a hardy sailor and diver, resolving to emulate his companion's bravery.

Dantès remained for a short time mute and motionless; at length he said:
“Then you abandon all hope of escape?”
“I perceive its utter impossibility; and I consider it impious to attempt that which the Almighty evidently does not approve.”
“Nay, be not discouraged. Would it not be expecting too much to hope to succeed at your first attempt? Why not try to find an opening in another direction from that which has so unfortunately failed?”
“Alas, it shows how little notion you can have of all it has cost me to effect a purpose so unexpectedly frustrated, that you talk of beginning over again. In the first place, I was four years making the tools I possess, and have been two years scraping and digging out earth, hard as granite itself; then what toil and fatigue has it not been to remove huge stones I should once have deemed impossible to loosen. Whole days have I passed in these Titanic efforts, considering my labor well repaid if, by night-time I had contrived to carry away a square inch of this hard-bound cement, changed by ages into a substance unyielding as the stones themselves; then to conceal the mass of earth and rubbish I dug up, I was compelled to break through a staircase, and throw the fruits of my labor into the hollow part of it; but the well is now so completely choked up, that I scarcely think it would be possible to add another handful of dust without leading to discovery. Consider also that I fully believed I had accomplished the end and aim of my undertaking, for which I had so exactly husbanded my strength as to make it just hold out to the termination of my enterprise; and now, at the moment when I reckoned upon success, my hopes are forever dashed from me. No, I repeat again, that nothing shall induce me to renew attempts evidently at variance with the Almighty’s pleasure.”
Dantès held down his head, that the other might not see how joy at the thought of having a companion outweighed the sympathy he felt for the failure of the abbé’s plans.
The abbé sank upon Edmond’s bed, while Edmond himself remained standing. Escape had never once occurred to him. There are, indeed, some things which appear so impossible that the mind does not dwell on them for an instant. To undermine the ground for fifty feet—to devote three years to a labor which, if successful, would conduct you to a precipice overhanging the sea—to plunge into the waves from the height of fifty, sixty, perhaps a hundred feet, at the risk of being dashed to pieces against the rocks, should you have been fortunate enough to have escaped the fire of the sentinels; and even, supposing all these perils past, then to have to swim for your life a distance of at least three miles ere you could reach the shore—were difficulties so startling and formidable that Dantès had never even dreamed of such a scheme, resigning himself rather to death.
But the sight of an old man clinging to life with so desperate a courage, gave a fresh turn to his ideas, and inspired him with new courage. Another, older and less strong than he, had attempted what he had not had sufficient resolution to undertake, and had failed only because of an error in calculation. This same person, with almost incredible patience and perseverance, had contrived to provide himself with tools requisite for so unparalleled an attempt. Another had done all this; why, then, was it impossible to Dantès? Faria had dug his way through fifty feet, Dantès would dig a hundred; Faria, at the age of fifty, had devoted three years to the task; he, who was but half as old, would sacrifice six; Faria, a priest and savant, had not shrunk from the idea of risking his life by trying to swim a distance of three miles to one of the islands—Daume, Rattonneau, or Lemaire; should a hardy sailor, an experienced diver, like himself, shrink from a similar task; should he, who had so often for mere amusement’s sake plunged to the bottom of the sea to fetch up the bright coral branch, hesitate to entertain the same project? He could do it in an hour, and how many times had he, for pure pastime, continued in the water for more than twice as long! At once Dantès resolved to follow the brave example of his energetic companion, and to remember that what has once been done may be done again.

Dantès remained for a short time mute and motionless; at length he said:—  

“You have, then, wholly abandoned the idea of escaping?”  

“I perceive its utter impossibility; and I consider it impious to attempt that which the Almighty evidently does not approve.”  

“Nay, be not so easily discouraged. Would it not be expecting too much to hope to succeed at your first attempt? Why not try to find an opening in another direction from that you have so carefully explored?”  

“But wherefore speak of what I have so carefully explored? All this was the work of long, long hours—of painful, indefatigable labor. At the moment when I reckoned upon success, my strength failed me; and now I say again, that since my efforts have been thus ineffectual, it is plain that nothing is to be accomplished by human means, and that my destiny is irrevocably fixed.”  

“But what induced you to persevere when you had lost all hope?”  

“It was my misfortune itself. I said to myself, ‘Here is one devoted to the service of God, who, by a miracle, has been conducted to a youth apparently forsaken of Heaven. If, through my means, this poor lad be restored to liberty and life, I shall not have lived in vain.’”  

“And how did you first commence this labor?”  

“I detached, one by one, the stones from the wall, working at them with the point of an old knife, and loosening them with a nail. After four years of incessant toil, I succeeded in getting out the first stone. You may judge of my joy. I then continued my labors, and at the end of two years more I had removed another. But, alas! the wall was six feet thick, and the stones were all cemented together with a coating of harder material than themselves. I had already been six years at this Herculean task, when I had only succeeded in removing three stones. I then despaired.”  

“Six years!” murmured Dantès.  

“Do not alarm yourself, young man,” replied Faria; “had it not been for an unforeseen circumstance, I should, in all probability, have completed my design.”  

“Unforeseen!—what was it?”  

“The gallery I was forming would have conducted me to the outer wall of the prison, and there I should have thrown myself into the sea, swam to one of the islands near the Château d’If—the Isle of Daume or the Isle of Tiboulen—and then have been safe.”  

“And could you have swum so far?”  

“Heaven would have given me strength; but now all is changed.”  

“All?”  

“Yes; listen. One evening as I was at work, I heard a noise. I listened—it was the sound of a file. I trembled lest it should be discovered that I was at work. I put out my light and listened. The sound continued. I then ascertained that it proceeded from the direction of your cell. I determined to investigate. I removed a stone, and saw you, pale, emaciated, and half dead. You had been without food for three days.”  

Dantès bowed his head in token of assent.  

“I then,” continued Faria, “made an opening large enough to admit your passage, and you entered. But how was I repaid for my trouble? You were no sooner restored than you sought to escape. You thought only of yourself. I risked my life to save yours, and you would have destroyed me.”  

“Forgive me,” cried Dantès, blushing with shame.  

“Nay,” returned the abbé, “it was natural. I am old and have no ties to bind me to life. You are young and full of hope. But let us speak no more of that. I am happy in having found a companion, even though it be but for a short time.”  

Dantès extended his hand and pressed that of Faria, who continued:—  

“I resolved to ascertain whether the gallery I had made was known to the jailers. I found that it was not; and this emboldened me to proceed. But I had not calculated on the strength of the materials. The rock was harder than I had supposed, and my tools were inadequate. Still I persevered, and at length, after incredible labor, I succeeded in removing another stone. But by this time I had been eleven years in prison.”  

“Eleven years!” exclaimed Dantès.  

“Yes, eleven years. And now judge of my despair when, after all this time, I found that instead of having, as I supposed, half accomplished my task, I had scarcely begun it. The wall was lined with a thick layer of granite, which I had not detected. I was compelled to commence anew.”  

Dantès could not suppress a cry of anguish.  

“I see now,” said Faria, “that you are capable of comprehending the extent of my misery. But do not pity me. I have borne it so long that it has become a part of my existence. Besides, I have a consolation.”  

“What is it?”  

“I write.”  

“You write?”  

“Yes; with this bone I write on this linen. But let me proceed with my narrative. When I found that the wall was lined with granite, I abandoned the idea of penetrating through it, and contented myself with enlarging the gallery already made. This I have done, and now it extends to the staircase, where it is concealed by a stone, which I can remove at pleasure. Into this recess I have introduced all the earth and stones I have taken out, and have filled up the opening so completely that no one could suspect its existence. It is here that I deposit my tools when I have done with them. And now, my young friend, since you know my history, let me hear yours.”  

---

This passage aligns with the provided metadata, capturing the dialogue between Dantès and Abbé Faria about the latter's failed escape attempt and its impact on Dantès' resolve.

The governor sighed, as though he had heard such protests a thousand times before. “Men always claim innocence when faced with death. It changes nothing.”  

Dantès’s mind raced. He thought of Mercédès, her dark eyes filled with tears the last time he had seen her. He thought of his father, old and frail, waiting for a son who would never return. The injustice of it all burned like fire in his veins.  

“At least tell me why,” he demanded, stepping forward. “What am I accused of? Who has done this to me?”  

The governor’s expression remained impassive. “I do not question the orders I receive. I carry them out.”  

A bitter laugh escaped Dantès. “So I am to die without even knowing my crime?”  

The governor turned away, signaling to the guards. “Take him back to his cell. The execution will take place at dawn.”  

The guards seized Dantès by the arms, their grip unyielding. He did not resist. What was the use? The machinery of fate had already been set in motion, and he was but a cog in its relentless gears.  

As they dragged him through the dim corridors of the prison, Dantès’s thoughts turned inward. He had once believed in the goodness of men, in the fairness of the world. Now, he saw only treachery and deceit. Villefort, Danglars, Fernand—they had conspired against him, stolen his life, his love, his future. And for what? Ambition? Jealousy? Cowardice?  

The cell door clanged shut behind him, the sound final as a tomb sealing. Dantès sank to his knees, his head bowed. He had endured years of solitude, clinging to the hope of freedom. Now, even that was gone.  

But as he knelt there in the darkness, something stirred within him—not despair, but fury. A cold, calculating rage that burned away his helplessness. If he was to die, then so be it. But if by some miracle he lived, he would not rest until those who had wronged him paid for their sins.  

He lifted his head, his eyes gleaming with a newfound resolve. “If God wills that I perish here, then let it be so,” he whispered. “But if I survive, I swear by all that is holy, I will have vengeance.”  

The words hung in the air like a vow, a promise to the shadows that surrounded him. And for the first time in years, Dantès felt something other than despair—he felt purpose.

events.title: A New Escape Plan and Faria's Moral Objection
detailed_summary: After a period of deep thought, Dantès excitedly announces to Faria that he has discovered what Faria was searching for, implying a new escape route.

He proposes they create a side opening from Faria's existing tunnel to intersect with the outer gallery, kill the sentinel guarding it, and escape, relying on Faria's courage and his own strength, and promising to match Faria's proven patience.
Faria gently interjects, explaining that Dantès misunderstands the nature of his courage and the intended use of his strength.
He clarifies that while his patience was exercised in his daily labor, undertaken with the belief he was liberating an innocent man, he cannot bring himself to commit murder.
Dantès is surprised, asking if encountering him has changed Faria's view on the guilt of attempting escape.
Faria responds that he does not wish to incur guilt, distinguishing between waging war against circumstances (like walls or staircases) and harming human beings, an act he cannot easily justify.
Dantès expresses astonishment that such a scruple would prevent Faria from seeking his liberty.
Faria counters by asking Dantès why he never considered overpowering his jailer and escaping in his clothes.
Dantès admits that such an idea simply never occurred to him.

Faria attributes this to a natural aversion to committing such a crime, an instinct that generally keeps people from straying from duty in simple matters, unlike a predatory animal that instinctively hunts. He suggests that human nature, beyond just societal laws, recoils from bloodshed.
Dantès is left confused and silent, recognizing the unspoken moral reasoning that Faria has articulated, distinguishing between ideas of the mind and those of the heart.

events.text_segment:
After continuing some time in profound meditation, the young man suddenly exclaimed, “I have found what you were in search of!”
Faria started: “Have you, indeed?” cried he, raising his head with quick anxiety; “pray, let me know what it is you have discovered?”
“The corridor through which you have bored your way from the cell you occupy here, extends in the same direction as the outer gallery, does it not?”
“It does.”
“And is not above fifteen feet from it?”
“About that.”
“Well, then, I will tell you what we must do. We must pierce through the corridor by forming a side opening about the middle, as it were the top part of a cross. This time you will lay your plans more accurately; we shall get out into the gallery you have described; kill the sentinel who guards it, and make our escape. All we require to insure success is courage, and that you possess, and strength, which I am not deficient in; as for patience, you have abundantly proved yours—you shall now see me prove mine.”
“One instant, my dear friend,” replied the abbé; “it is clear you do not understand the nature of the courage with which I am endowed, and what use I intend making of my strength. As for patience, I consider that I have abundantly exercised that in beginning every morning the task of the night before, and every night renewing the task of the day. But then, young man (and I pray of you to give me your full attention), then I thought I could not be doing anything displeasing to the Almighty in trying to set an innocent being at liberty—one who had committed no offence, and merited not condemnation.”
“And have your notions changed?” asked Dantès with much surprise; “do you think yourself more guilty in making the attempt since you have encountered me?”

Dantès was confused and silent at this explanation of the thoughts which had unconsciously been working in his mind, or rather soul; for there are two distinct sorts of ideas, those that proceed from the head and those that emanate from the heart.

Dantès was mute with astonishment.

“Yet you would not hesitate to shed your own?”

“But a man who has made up his mind to die, does not commit suicide.”  

“It is a matter of conscience,” said Faria.  

Dantès stood before him in mute amazement.  

“I have often heard of such scruples,” said he, at length; “but they never stood in the way of any one’s liberty before.”  

“But they have stood in the way of many men’s consciences,” replied Faria.  

“Well,” said Dantès, “how would you propose to act?”  

“I would propose,” replied Faria, “that we should continue our labours, and wait for some favourable opportunity of leaving the prison without having recourse to violence.”  

Dantès uttered an exclamation of impatience.  

“You are a man of patience,” said he.  

“Because I have been so long a prisoner,” replied Faria.  

“But,” said Dantès, “you would not have me wait for years?”  

“No, but I would have you wait for months.”  

“But the sentinel?”  

“We will not kill him.”  

“But he will see us.”  

“He is short-sighted.”  

“He will hear us.”  

“He is deaf.”  

Dantès burst into a fit of laughter.  

“Upon my word,” said he, “I see you have arranged everything.”  

“Yes,” replied Faria, “I have always had a taste for such contrivances.”  

“But,” said Dantès, “if you had not been interrupted, how far would you have proceeded with your work?”  

“Possibly to the end.”  

“How long would it have taken you?”  

“About three years.”  

Dantès shuddered.  

“Well,” said Faria, “I can understand that a sailor would not care to wait so long.”  

“Have you, then, no hope but this?”  

“None.”  

“Then,” said Dantès, “let me tell you what I have discovered.”  

“Speak,” said Faria.  

“I have discovered that the gallery you speak of is precisely above us.”  

“Are you sure of that?”  

“Perfectly. When I was taken to your cell, I remarked the direction of the corridor; it leads straight under the gallery. The distance between the gallery and the corridor is not more than fifteen feet, and we have only to pierce through the ceiling.”  

“But,” said Faria, “we might be heard at work.”  

“No; for we will work only at night, when the sentinel is asleep.”  

“But,” said Faria, “I cannot consent to this.”  

“And why?”  

“Because it would be making you an accomplice in my escape, and I cannot bear the idea of your being punished on my account.”  

Dantès was again silent.  

“Then,” said he, at length, “we will remain as we are?”  

Faria smiled.  

“We will remain,” said he, “and you shall see what patience can effect.”  

“Then,” said Dantès, “let us proceed with our work.”  

“Willingly,” replied Faria.  

And he took up his chisel, while Dantès resumed his labour.

After continuing some time in profound meditation, the young man suddenly exclaimed, “I have found what you were in search of!”  

Edmond Dantès, his eyes alight with triumph, turned to the aged Abbé Faria, who lay weak and frail upon the straw pallet in their shared cell. The flickering torchlight cast long shadows across the damp stone walls of the Château d’If, but in that moment, the darkness seemed to recede before the brilliance of Dantès’ discovery.  

Faria, though weakened by years of imprisonment and illness, raised himself slightly, his keen intellect undimmed. “Speak, my son,” he urged, his voice a whisper. “What have you uncovered?”  

Dantès knelt beside him, his hands trembling with excitement. “The treasure of the Spadas!” he declared. “The riddle that has eluded scholars for centuries—I have solved it!”  

Faria’s eyes widened. “How?”  

With a piece of charcoal salvaged from their meager fire, Dantès sketched upon the wall the intricate cipher Faria had once shown him—the coded testament of Cardinal Spada, which hinted at an immense fortune hidden away from the greed of the Borgias. “The key was in the phrasing,” Dantès explained eagerly. “The words were not merely poetic but a map—a guide to the island of Monte Cristo!”  

Faria listened intently as Dantès unraveled the mystery, his mind racing alongside his protégé’s. The young man’s intelligence, sharpened by years of suffering and the Abbé’s teachings, had pierced the veil of the past. “Yes,” Faria murmured at last, a faint smile touching his lips. “It must be so. You have done what I could not.”  

But even as joy filled Dantès’ heart, a shadow crossed his face. “Yet what use is this knowledge to us now?” he asked bitterly, gesturing to the iron bars that caged them. “We are prisoners, doomed to rot in this place.”  

Faria’s hand, thin and trembling, clasped Dantès’ wrist with surprising strength. “No, Edmond,” he said firmly. “You must not despair. I am old, and my body fails me, but you—you are young, strong. You must escape. You must claim the treasure and fulfill the destiny that God has laid before you.”  

Dantès shook his head. “I will not leave you.”  

“You must,” Faria insisted. “Promise me that when I am gone, you will find a way. Swear it.”  

Tears welled in Dantès’ eyes, but he nodded. “I swear it.”  

Days passed, and Faria’s condition worsened. On the eve of his death, he called Dantès to his side one final time. “Remember,” he whispered, “vengeance is God’s, but justice… justice may yet be yours.” With those words, the Abbé breathed his last, leaving Dantès alone in the darkness.  

But the fire of resolve burned brighter than ever in Dantès’ heart. Faria’s teachings, the secret of the Spada treasure, and the injustices that had condemned him to this hell—all fused into a single, unshakable purpose.  

And so, when the opportunity came, Dantès acted. Feigning his own death, he was sewn into a burial sack and cast into the sea. But the sea, which had once taken so much from him, now granted him freedom. Cutting his way free, he emerged reborn—no longer the naïve sailor Edmond Dantès, but a man forged in suffering, ready to claim his destiny.  

The island of Monte Cristo awaited him, and with it, the means to reward those who had shown him kindness and to punish those who had betrayed him. The Count of Monte Cristo had begun his ascent.

events.text_segment:
“Since my imprisonment,” said Faria, “I have thought over all the most celebrated cases of escape on record. They have rarely been successful. Those that have been crowned with full success have been long meditated upon, and carefully arranged; such, for instance, as the escape of the Duc de Beaufort from the Château de Vincennes, that of the Abbé Dubuquoi from For l’Evêque; of Latude from the Bastille. Then there are those for which chance sometimes affords opportunity, and those are the best of all. Let us, therefore, wait patiently for some favorable moment, and when it presents itself, profit by it.”
“Ah,” said Dantès, “you might well endure the tedious delay; you were constantly employed in the task you set yourself, and when weary with toil, you had your hopes to refresh and encourage you.”
“I assure you,” replied the old man, “I did not turn to that source for recreation or support.”
“What did you do then?”
“I wrote or studied.”
“Were you then permitted the use of pens, ink, and paper?”
“Oh, no,” answered the abbé; “I had none but what I made for myself.”
“You made paper, pens and ink?”
“Yes.”
Dantès gazed with admiration, but he had some difficulty in believing. Faria saw this.
“When you pay me a visit in my cell, my young friend,” said he, “I will show you an entire work, the fruits of the thoughts and reflections of my whole life; many of them meditated over in the shades of the Colosseum at Rome, at the foot of St. Mark’s column at Venice, and on the borders of the Arno at Florence, little imagining at the time that they would be arranged in order within the walls of the Château d’If. The work I speak of is called A Treatise on the Possibility of a General Monarchy in Italy, and will make one large quarto volume.”
“And on what have you written all this?”
“On two of my shirts. I invented a preparation that makes linen as smooth and as easy to write on as parchment.”
“You are, then, a chemist?”
“Somewhat; I know Lavoisier, and was the intimate friend of Cabanis.”
“But for such a work you must have needed books—had you any?”
“I had nearly five thousand volumes in my library at Rome; but after reading them over many times, I found out that with one hundred and fifty well-chosen books a man possesses, if not a complete summary of all human knowledge, at least all that a man need really know. I devoted three years of my life to reading and studying these one hundred and fifty volumes, till I knew them nearly by heart; so that since I have been in prison, a very slight effort of memory has enabled me to recall their contents as readily as though the pages were open before me. I could recite you the whole of Thucydides, Xenophon, Plutarch, Titus Livius, Tacitus, Strada, Jornandes, Dante, Montaigne, Shakespeare, Spinoza, Machiavelli, and Bossuet. I name only the most important.”
“You are, doubtless, acquainted with a variety of languages, so as to have been able to read all these?”
“Yes, I speak five of the modern tongues—that is to say, German, French, Italian, English, and Spanish; by the aid of ancient Greek I learned modern Greek—I don’t speak it so well as I could wish, but I am still trying to improve myself.”
“Improve yourself!” repeated Dantès; “why, how can you manage to do so?”
“Why, I made a vocabulary of the words I knew; turned, returned, and arranged them, so as to enable me to express my thoughts through their medium. I know nearly one thousand words, which is all that is absolutely necessary, although I believe there are nearly one hundred thousand in the dictionaries. I cannot hope to be very fluent, but I certainly should have no difficulty in explaining my wants and wishes; and that would be quite as much as I should ever require.”
Stronger grew the wonder of Dantès, who almost fancied he had to do with one gifted with supernatural powers; still hoping to find some imperfection which might bring him down to a level with human beings, he added, “Then if you were not furnished with pens, how did you manage to write the work you speak of?”
“I made myself some excellent ones, which would be universally preferred to all others if once known. You are aware what huge whitings are served to us on maigre days. Well, I selected the cartilages of the heads of these fishes, and you can scarcely imagine the delight with which I welcomed the arrival of each Wednesday, Friday, and Saturday, as affording me the means of increasing my stock of pens; for I will freely confess that my historical labors have been my greatest solace and relief. While retracing the past, I forget the present; and traversing at will the path of history I cease to remember that I am myself a prisoner.”
“But the ink,” said Dantès; “of what did you make your ink?”
“There was formerly a fireplace in my dungeon,” replied Faria, “but it was closed up long ere I became an occupant of this prison. Still, it must have been many years in use, for it was thickly covered with a coating of soot; this soot I dissolved in a portion of the wine brought to me every Sunday, and I assure you a better ink cannot be desired. For very important notes, for which closer attention is required, I pricked one of my fingers, and wrote with my own blood.”
“And when,” asked Dantès, “may I see all this?”
“Whenever you please,” replied the abbé.
“Oh, then let it be directly!” exclaimed the young man.
“Follow me, then,” said the abbé, as he re-entered the subterranean passage, in which he soon disappeared, followed by Dantès.

The work I speak of is called *A Treatise on the Possibility of a General Monarchy in Italy*, and will make one large quarto volume."**  

**"And on what have you written all this?"**  

**"On two of my shirts. I invented a preparation that makes linen as smooth and as easy to write on as parchment."**  

**"You are, then, a chemist?"**  

**"Somewhat; I knew Lavoisier, and was the intimate friend of Cabanis."**  

**"But for such a work you must have needed books—had you any?"**  

**"I had nearly five thousand volumes in my library at Rome; but after reading them over many times, I found out that with one hundred and fifty well-chosen books a man possesses, if not a complete summary of all human knowledge, at least all that a man need really know. I devoted three years of my life to reading and studying these one hundred and fifty volumes, till I knew them nearly by heart; so that since I have been in prison, a very slight effort of memory has enabled me to recall their contents as readily as though the pages were open before me. I could recite you the whole of Thucydides, Xenophon, Plutarch, Titus Livius, Tacitus, Strada, Jornandès, Dante, Montaigne, Shakespeare, Spinoza, Machiavelli, and Bossuet. I mention only the most important."**  

**"You are, doubtless, acquainted with a variety of languages, so as to have been able to read all these?"**  

**"Yes; I speak five modern languages—German, French, Italian, English, and Spanish. By the help of ancient Greek I learned modern Greek—I don’t speak it so well as I could wish, but I am still trying to improve myself."**  

**"Improve yourself!" repeated Dantès; "why, how can you manage to do so?"**  

**"Why, I made a vocabulary of the words I knew; turned, returned, and arranged them, so as to enable me to express my thoughts through their medium. I know nearly one thousand words, which is all that is absolutely necessary, although I believe there are nearly one hundred thousand in the dictionaries. I cannot hope to be very fluent, but I certainly should have no difficulty in explaining my wants and wishes; and that would be quite as much as I should ever require."**

**"But the pens—how did you make them?"**  

**"Oh, they were easily made. I knew that the so-called ‘whiting’ fish of the Mediterranean were to be found in the bay close by, so I resolved to make use of them. I begged for the heads of these fish, and obtained them. From these heads I extracted the cartilages, which you see here. These I cut into proper shapes, and they make excellent pens, far preferable, indeed, to quills, as they retain their points much longer. Thus, you see, I had my writing materials ready to hand whenever I wished to write."**  

**"And the ink?" said Dantès; "how did you procure that?"**  

**"There was formerly a fireplace in my dungeon," replied Faria, "and it was closed up some time before my arrival. I dissolved the soot from this chimney in a portion of the wine brought to me on Sundays, for I was occasionally allowed that indulgence. This formed an excellent ink. For very important notes, for which I wished to secure durability, I pricked one of my fingers, and wrote with my own blood."**

**"Oh, then let it be directly!" exclaimed the young man.**

They have been many, but few have been successful. The reason is simple: most prisoners lack the patience, the resources, or the intelligence to overcome the obstacles before them. Yet, I have studied them all—from the legendary flight of the Man in the Iron Mask to the cunning stratagems of Latude. Each has taught me something, and from their failures, I have learned even more.”

Edmond Dantès listened with rapt attention, his eyes fixed on the old man’s face. Faria’s voice, though weakened by years of confinement, carried the weight of deep thought and relentless determination. 

“Consider,” Faria continued, “the case of Benvenuto Cellini, the great artist who escaped from the Castel Sant’Angelo. He fashioned ropes from his bedsheets and descended from his cell. A bold plan, but one that required strength and agility—qualities that diminish with age. Then there was Baron Trenck, who dug his way out of the fortress of Magdeburg. Ah, but he had tools, and accomplices, and time. We have none of these luxuries.”

Dantès felt a flicker of despair at these words, but Faria’s next sentence rekindled his hope. 

“Yet,” the abbé said, his eyes gleaming, “there is one method that has never been attempted here, in the Château d’If. A method so simple, so audacious, that it might just succeed where others have failed.” 

“What is it?” Dantès whispered, leaning forward. 

Faria lowered his voice, though the thick walls of their dungeon made eavesdropping unlikely. “We shall tunnel through the rock—not upward, toward the guarded courtyards, but downward, beneath the foundations of the prison.” 

Dantès frowned. “But the sea surrounds us on all sides. Even if we could dig so far, we would drown in the attempt.” 

Faria smiled. “Ah, my young friend, you forget—the Château d’If is built upon rock, but that rock is porous. There are natural fissures, channels carved by the sea over centuries. If we can find one of these passages, we may reach the water safely and swim to freedom.” 

The enormity of the plan struck Dantès like a physical blow. “But how? We have no tools, no light, no way to know if such passages even exist.” 

Faria reached beneath his ragged mattress and drew out a rusted nail. “This,” he said, “is our first tool. With patience, we can fashion others. As for light, we shall use the tallow from our meals to make candles. And as for the passages…” He tapped his temple. “I have studied the geology of these islands. The sea has worn away at the rock for millennia. There *must* be a way.” 

Dantès felt a surge of admiration for the old man’s indomitable spirit. “Then we begin tonight.” 

Faria nodded. “But remember, Edmond, this will not be the work of days, or even months. It may take years. We must proceed with the utmost caution, for if the guards suspect our plan, all is lost.” 

“Years…” Dantès repeated, the word heavy on his tongue. He had already spent so many in this hellish place. Could he endure more? 

As if reading his thoughts, Faria placed a gnarled hand on his shoulder. “Time is our ally, not our enemy. Every day weakens our jailers’ vigilance and strengthens our resolve. And when we are free—” His voice grew fierce. “When we are free, we shall reclaim what was stolen from us.” 

Dantès thought of Mercédès, of his father, of Danglars and Fernand, who had betrayed him. A fire ignited in his chest. “Yes,” he said. “We will.” 

And so, that very night, they began their labor. With the rusted nail, they scratched at the mortar between the stones of Faria’s cell, loosening a block inch by agonizing inch. The work was slow, their hands bled, but neither complained. Each small victory—a loosened stone, a handful of debris smuggled away in their pockets—was a step toward freedom. 

Weeks turned into months. The tunnel grew deeper, their tools more refined. A spoon stolen during mealtime became a digging implement; a broken chair leg served as a lever. Faria, with his vast knowledge, devised a way to disperse the excavated earth by scattering it in the prison yard during their rare moments of outdoor exercise. 

One evening, as they worked in the flickering light of a tallow candle, Faria paused, his ear pressed to the tunnel wall. “Listen,” he breathed. 

Dantès strained his ears. At first, he heard nothing. Then—a faint, distant sound, like the sigh of the ocean. 

“The sea,” Faria whispered. “We are close.” 

Dantès’s heart pounded. For the first time in years, he allowed himself to truly believe in freedom. 

But fate, as ever, was cruel. The next day, before they could resume their work, the guards came for Faria. The old man, in a fit of coughing, had collapsed during exercise, and the prison doctor, suspecting contagion, ordered him moved to the infirmary. 

As they dragged him away, Faria locked eyes with Dantès. “Remember the plan,” he gasped. “Do not lose hope.” 

Then he was gone. 

Alone once more, Dantès stood in the center of the cell, his fists clenched. The tunnel, their precious work, lay hidden beneath the loosened stone. But without Faria, could he continue? 

He thought of the old man’s words, of the years they had spent planning, digging, dreaming. No. He would not let their efforts be in vain. 

That night, he returned to the tunnel. The work was harder alone, the silence heavier, but he pressed on. Each scrape of the nail against rock was a defiance of his captors, a promise to himself and to Faria. 

And as he dug, he swore an oath—not just to escape, but to punish those who had wronged him. 

The Count of Monte Cristo would rise from the depths of the sea, and his vengeance would be terrible.
